unnormalised: A recent report from the Indian Statistical Institute (ISI) Kolkata shows that 65% of students find probability and statistics harder than other subjects. Seems like a lot of folks are struggling, huh? The survey, conducted across 1000 schools in India, also indicated that the avg. score in stats tests was only 45/100. Ouch!
normalised: A recent report from the I-S-I Kolkata shows that sixty five percent of students find probability and statistics harder than other subjects. Seems like a lot of folks are struggling, huh? The survey, conducted across one thousand schools in India, also indicated that the average score in statistics tests was only forty five divided by one hundred. Ouch!

unnormalised: Prof. Sharma from IIT Delhi, commenting on the findings, said, "The problem often lies in the teaching methods. We need more practical, real-world examples, not just theoretical equations." He suggested using simulations, like coin flips (50/50 chance, right?) or dice rolls, to make the concepts easier to grasp.

unnormalised: The report also highlighted regional disparities. In states like Kerala, the average score was 52, whereas in Bihar, it was only 38. Experts believe this is due to differences in teacher training and resource availability.

unnormalised: To combat this, the Ministry of Education has announced a new initiative to provide free online resources and tutoring for students struggling with probability and stats. The goal is to raise the average score by at least 10% in the next academic year.
